content: The Act titled "National Park System Reform Act of 1994" includes the preparation of a National Park System Plan. The National Park System Reform Act of 1994 mandates the Secretary of the Interior to prepare a National Park System Plan. This plan will define goals, criteria for resource inclusion, representation of national heritage, and identification of appropriate aspects of the national heritage. The National Park System Reform Act of 1994 mandates the Secretary of the Interior to prepare a National Park System Plan, which includes defining goals, criteria for resource inclusion, representation of national heritage, priorities for adding themes and resources, and outlining the role of the National Park Service. Consultation with other Federal land entities is also required during the plan's preparation. The National Park System Reform Act of 1994 mandates the Secretary of the Interior to prepare a National Park System Plan, which includes consultation with other Federal land managing agencies, State and local officials, the National Park System Advisory Board, and other interested parties. The plan must be transmitted to Congress within three fiscal years after enactment. SEC. 102. MANAGEMENT REVIEW OF NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. The Secretary will review the National Park System to determine if there are better management alternatives, considering factors like duplication, lack of significance, and cost. A report will be developed listing areas where National Park Service management should be modified or terminated. The Secretary will review the National Park System to assess management alternatives based on factors like duplication, lack of significance, and cost. Recommendations for areas where National Park Service management should be changed or terminated will be made, with consultation from various stakeholders and entities for input and feedback. The Secretary will consult with various stakeholders and organizations to gather input on recommendations for modifications or termination of National Park Service management for certain areas within the National Park System. The report will be transmitted to Congress within 1 year after the completion of the plan. SEC. 103. NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM REVIEW COMMISSION. Establishment of Commission: If the Secretary fails to transmit the report within the specified time, a National Park System Review Commission will review existing units for possible alternative management. The Commission will submit a report to Congress with recommendations for modifying or terminating National Park Service management in certain areas. Feasible alternatives to National Park Service management will be identified for areas of national significance before inclusion on the list. The Commission, consisting of 7 members familiar with the National Park System, will identify alternatives to National Park Service management for areas of national significance. Consultations will be held with various stakeholders, including Federal land managing agencies, State and local officials, and the public. Appointments to the Commission will be made by the Secretary, Speaker of the House, and President Pro Tem of the Senate. The Commission, consisting of 7 members, will be appointed by various officials. The Commission will elect a chair from its members, fill vacancies promptly, and meet quarterly. Members will serve without compensation but will be entitled to travel expenses for official business. The Commission established will terminate 90 days after the report is transmitted to Congress. The Commission may hire staff, with limitations on National Park Service employees. Other federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission. The Commission may also procure temporary experts and consultants. The Commission may detail personnel from Federal agencies on a reimbursable basis to assist in its work. It can also procure temporary services and make necessary bylaws and regulations. Members or agents of the Commission can take actions authorized by the Commission, and it has the authority to use the United States mails. The Commission is authorized to take actions and use the United States mails. The Secretary must provide requested information relevant to the Commission's duties. SEC. 201. STUDY OF NEW PARK SYSTEM AREAS. Section 8 of the Act of August 18, 1970 is amended to include a new subsection (b) requiring the Secretary to submit a list of areas recommended for study for potential inclusion in the National Park System to the appropriate committees annually. The Secretary must annually submit a list of areas recommended for study for potential inclusion in the National Park System to the House of Representatives and Senate committees. Consideration is given to areas meeting criteria of national significance, suitability, and feasibility, with special attention to themes, sites, and resources not well-represented in the National Park System. No new studies for inclusion can be initiated without specific congressional authorization. The Secretary must complete studies for potential National Park System inclusion within 3 fiscal years of specific legislation enactment. Public involvement is required, including at least one meeting near the area. The Secretary must conduct studies for potential National Park System inclusion within 3 fiscal years of specific legislation enactment. Public involvement is required, including at least one meeting near the area. Studies consider factors like resources' rarity, threats, public use potential, and costs. The Secretary conducts studies for potential National Park System inclusion within 3 fiscal years of specific legislation enactment. Factors considered include resources' rarity, threats, public use potential, costs, and public involvement. Each study identifies the most effective and efficient management option for protecting resources and providing public enjoyment. The Secretary submits a list of areas at the beginning of each calendar year along with the annual budget submission. The Secretary submits a list of areas at the beginning of each calendar year to Congress, containing recommendations for the Administration's preferred management options for areas previously studied for National Park System inclusion. The House of Representatives passed the document on September 28, 1994, with Donnald K. Anderson as the Clerk.
